newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Kohl seen as key to Czech support for post-war pact.
newsitem.headline: Kohl seen as key to Czech support for post-war pact.

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's visit to Prague next week will be key to winning broad Czech support for a post-World War Two reconciliation accord between the two countries, a senior Czech diplomat said on Tuesday.

Czech officials want the accord to receive wide backing from Czech MPs and that could be determined by Kohl's words and actions during his two-day visit, said the diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity.
"There are no worries that it will not pass, but we want it to have large support and honest acceptance...it depends a lot on what Chancellor Kohl says in Prague," he said.

The Czech Republic and Germany concluded nearly two years of delicate negotiations in December on the text of a joint declaration aimed at ending ill-feeling and suspicion lingering after World War Two and its aftermath.
Kohl and Czech Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus are due to sign the accord next Tuesday but it must subsequently be approved by both parliaments.
"If Kohl talks only about Germany, it would be too bad for the debate," the official said.
In the text, Bonn expresses sorrow over the 1938-45 Nazi occupation of the Czech lands. Prague expresses its regret for Czech brutality in the post-war expulsion of ethnic Germans.
The declaration was approved by both governments, which have said it should not be changed by their parliaments.
The Bonn parliament will debate the declaration next week and the Czech parliament will consider it in early February.

The Czech centre-right ruling coalition, which is two seats short of a majority in the parliament, fully supports the pact while the main opposition partner says it still has some concerns about the text.
Two other minor opposition parties see the pact as unacceptable.
